Tutorial for sensitivity analysis of an harmonic oscillator¶

Introduction¶

This tutorial demonstrates how to perform sensitivity analysis of a damped harmonic oscillator using the library provided by this repository.

The model can be described by the following system of ODEs:

\[\begin{split}\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x}\\ \dot{v} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} v\\ -kx - \mu v \end{bmatrix},\end{split}\]

where \(x\) is the displacement relative to the equilibrium position, \(v\) is the velocity, \(k\) is the spring constant and \(\mu\) is the damping coefficient.

Define the ODE system¶

Mathematically, the state of the ODE system is an \(n\)-dimensional vector of real or complex numbers (this library only supports real numbers). In this library, the state of the system is represented by the std::vector<T> container type, where T is a template parameter.

The ODE system is assumed to be in the form \(\dot{\mathbf{r}}(t) = f(\mathbf{r},\alpha,t)\), where \(\mathbf{r}\) is the state vector, \(\alpha\) is the parameter vector and \(t\) is the time. We will assume that \(k = 1\), so:

\[\begin{split}\mathbf{r} = \begin{bmatrix} x\\ v \end{bmatrix} \qquad \alpha = \begin{bmatrix} \mu \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]

The ODE system is defined by defining a functor that implements the right hand side \(f\) with the ()-operator with a specific signature:

class HarmonicOscillator
{
private:
    double k = 1.0;

public:
    HarmonicOscillator() = default;

    template <typename T>
    void operator()(const std::vector<T> &r,std::vector<T> &drdt,const std::vector<T> &mu,const T t) const
    {
        drdt[0] = r[1];
        drdt[1] = - k * r[0] - mu[0] * r[1];
    }
};

Notice how parameters that we don’t wish to differentiate with respect to can be defined as class attributes (double k = 1.0), while the parameters we wish to differentiate with respect to are passed to the ()-operator as std::vector<T> &mu.

The signature of the ()-operator must always be the same as it is shown in the code above. The ()-operator must be templated to allow the definition of the system function only once, since a version of the system function with T = double is needed by the stepper and a version with T = idouble is need by the AADC library to record the rhs with automatic differentiation. It is also possible to define two versions of the functor, one for T = double and another for T = idouble and pass each version to the correct place. This, however, is uglier code.

Define the Stepper Type¶

This library uses the boost::numeric::odeint steppers to solve the ODE system.

typedef odeint::runge_kutta4<std::vector<double>> stepper_type;

In this example we are using a constant step stepper, the classic 4th-ordr Runge-Kutta method.

Performing sensitivity analysis¶

Assume that we wish to find the sensitivities of the mechanical energy of the harmonic oscillator at \(t = t_f\) with respect to the initial conditions \(\left[x(t_i),v(t_i)\right]^T\) and damping coefficient \(\mu\). The mechanical energy, which is the objective function, is given by:

\[E(t_f) = \frac{1}{2}kx(t_f)^2 + \frac{1}{2}mv(t_f)^2\]

where \(m = 1.0\).

We need to create an instance of the Driver class,

// System size
int Nin = 2;
// Number of cost functions
int Nout = 1;
// Number of parameters
int Npar = 1;

Driver driver(Nin, Nout, Npar);

which is the construct that stores the trajectory of the ODE system.

Forward Pass¶

We need to set the initial conditions, initial and final time, time step and the value of the parameter \(\mu\):

// Time interval and time step
double ti = 0.0, tf = 10.0, dt = 0.01;

std::vector<double> mu = {0.15};
std::vector<double> r0 = {0.0, 1.0};

For this choice of damping coefficient, the harmonic oscillator is underdamped. We then solve the ODE by doing a forward pass,

// Create a stepper instance
stepper_type stepper;
// Create the system function instance
auto hm = HarmonicOscillator();

// Forward pass
size_t numSteps = runge_kutta(stepper, hm, r0, mu, ti, tf, dt, driver);

and the solution is stored in r0.

Reverse Pass¶

We set the partial derivatives of the cost function with respect to the state vector solution of the ODE (\(\left[x(t_f),v(t_f)\right]^T\)) and with respect to the parameter \(\mu\),

auto lambda = std::vector(Nout, std::vector<double>(Nin));
lambda[0][0] = 1.0 * r0[0]; // dE(t_f)dx(t_f) = k * x(t_f)
lambda[0][1] = 1.0 * r0[1]; // dE(t_f)dv(t_f) = m * v(t_f)

auto muadj = std::vector(Nout, std::vector<double>(Npar));
muadj[0][0] = 0.0; // dE(t_f)d\mu = 0.0

// Set derivatives of cost functions w.r.t ODE solution and w.r.t. parameters
setCostGradients(driver, lambda, muadj);

Additionally, we need to inform the driver of the chosen stepper’same Butcher Tableau,

constructDriverButcherTableau(driver, stepper);

and to record the rhs function with automatic differentiation,

recordDriverRHSFunction(driver, hm);

we perform a reverse pass by doing:

// Reverse pass to obtain the adjoints of the cost functions
backpropagation::adjointSolve(driver, mu);

The sensitivities are stored in lambda and muadj.
